categories.name: Quickstart
categories.description: A survey of basic functionality in ScottPlot 5

categories.name: Annotation
categories.description: Annotations are always-visible text labels positioned over the data area.

categories.name: Arrow
categories.description: Arrows point to a location in coordinate space.

categories.name: Axis Lines
categories.description: Axis lines indicate a position on an axis.

categories.name: Axis Spans
categories.description: Axis spans indicate a range of an axis.

categories.name: Bar Plot
categories.description: Bar plots represent values as horizontal or vertical rectangles

categories.name: Box Plot
categories.description: Box plots show a distribution at a glance

categories.name: Callout
categories.description: Callouts display a label and are connected with an arrow that marks a point on the plot.

categories.name: Contour Plot
categories.description: A contour plot is a graphical representation that shows the three-dimensional surface of a function on a two-dimensional plane by connecting points of equal value with contour lines

categories.name: Coxcomb Plot
categories.description: A Coxcomb chart is a pie graph where the angle of slices is constant but the radii are not.

categories.name: Crosshair
categories.description: A Crosshair combines a horizontal axis line and vertical axis line to mark a location in coordinate space.

categories.name: Ellipse
categories.description: Ellipses are curves with a defined center and distinct X and Y radii. A circle is an ellipse with an X radius equal to its Y radius.

categories.name: Error Bars
categories.description: Error Bars communicate the range of possible values for a measurement

categories.name: FillY plot
categories.description: FillY plots display the vertical range between two Y values at defined X positions

categories.name: Financial Plot
categories.description: Finance plots display price data binned into time ranges

categories.name: Function
categories.description: Function plots are a type of line plot where Y positions are defined by a function that depends on X rather than a collection of discrete data points.

categories.name: Heatmap
categories.description: Heatmaps display values from 2D data as an image with cells of different intensities

categories.name: Images
categories.description: Images can be placed on plots in a variety of ways

categories.name: Line Plot
categories.description: Line plots can be placed on the plot in coordinate space using a Start, End, and an optional LineStyle.

categories.name: Lollipop Plot
categories.description: A lollipop chart is a variation of a bar chart that uses a line (stem) extending from a baseline to a marker (head) to represent data points. Lollipop highlight individual data points with less visual clutter than to traditional bar charts.

categories.name: Marker
categories.description: Markers can be placed on the plot in coordinate space.

categories.name: Phasor Plot
categories.description: Phasor plots display vectors on a radial axis centered at the origin

categories.name: Pie
categories.description: Pie charts illustrate numerical proportions as slices of a circle.

categories.name: Polar Axis
categories.description: Create a polar axis and add it to the plot to display data on a circular coordinate system.

categories.name: Population Plot
categories.description: Population plots display collections of individual values.

categories.name: Radar Plot
categories.description: Radar charts (also called a spider charts or star charts) represent multi-axis data as a 2D shape on axes arranged circularly around a center point.

categories.name: Radial gauge
categories.description: A radial gauge chart displays scalar data as circular gauges.

categories.name: Scale Bar
categories.description: Scalebars display a horizontal and/or vertical range using a line segment and may be used to convey axis scale as a minimal alternative to using axis frames, ticks, and tick labels.

categories.name: Scatter Plot
categories.description: Scatter plots display points at X/Y locations in coordinate space.

categories.name: Shapes
categories.description: Basic shapes that can be added to plots

categories.name: Signal Plot
categories.description: Signal plots display evenly-spaced data

categories.name: SignalConst
categories.description: SignalConst is a type of signal plot which contains immutable data points and occupies more memory but offers greater performance for extremely large datasets. It is rarely needed, but best use for plotting data containing millions of points.

categories.name: SignalXY Plot
categories.description: SignalXY are a high performance plot type optimized for X/Y pairs where the X values are always ascending. For large datasets SignalXY plots are much more performant than Scatter plots (which allow unordered X points) but not as performant as Signal plots (which require fixed spacing between X points).

categories.name: Text
categories.description: Text labels can be placed on the plot in coordinate space

categories.name: Vector Field
categories.description: Vector fields display a collection of vectors rooted at points in coordinate space

categories.name: Plottable Management
categories.description: How to add, remove, and reorder items in plots

categories.name: Layout
categories.description: How to customize data area size and figure padding

categories.name: Multiplot
categories.description: Use Multiplot to create figures with multiple subplots

categories.name: Histogram
categories.description: Histograms graphically represent the distribution of numerical data by grouping values into ranges (bins) and displaying the frequency or count of points in each bin.

categories.name: Internationalization
categories.description: Using ScottPlot across cultures with different text and numeric requirements.

categories.name: Regression
categories.description: Statistical operations to fit lines to data

categories.name: Customizing Grids
categories.description: Advanced customization of grid lines

categories.name: Miscellaneous
categories.description: Miscellaneous features and customization options

categories.name: Multiple Axes
categories.description: Tick mark customization and creation of multi-Axis plots

categories.name: Customizing Ticks
categories.description: Advanced customization of tick marks and tick labels

categories.name: Axis and Ticks
categories.description: Examples of common customizations for axis labels and ticks

categories.name: Legends
categories.description: A legend is a key typically displayed in the corner of a plot

categories.name: Styling Plots
categories.description: How to customize appearance of plots

recipes.name: Set Axis Limits
recipes.description: Axis Limits can be set by the user.

recipes.name: Read Axis Limits
recipes.description: Use GetLimits() to obtain the current axis limits.

recipes.name: AutoScale Axis Limits to Fit Data
recipes.description: The axis limits can be automatically adjusted to fit the data. Optional arguments allow users to define the amount of whitespace around the edges of the data.In older versions of ScottPlot this functionality was achieved by a method named AxisAuto().

recipes.name: Inverted Axis
recipes.description: Users can display data on an inverted axis by setting axis limits setting the lower edge to a value more positive than the upper edge.

recipes.name: Inverted Auto-Axis
recipes.description: Customize the logic for the automatic axis scaler to ensure that axis limits for a particular axis are always inverted when autoscaled.

recipes.name: Square Axis Units
recipes.description: Axis rules can be put in place which force the vertical scale (units per pixel) to match the horizontal scale so circles always appear as circles and not stretched ellipses.

recipes.name: Axis with Subtitle
recipes.description: Users can create their own fully custom axes to replace the default ones (as demonstrated in the demo app). Some experimental axes are available for users who may be interested in alternative axis display styles.

recipes.name: Axis AntiAliasing
recipes.description: To improve crispness of straight vertical and horizontal lines, Anti-aliasing is disabled by default for axis frames, tick marks, and grid lines. Anti-aliasing can be enabled for all these objects by calling the AntiAlias helper method.

recipes.name: Hide Axis and Turn frame lines on/off
recipes.description: Demonstrates how to hide axis ticks and turn frame lines on and off.

recipes.name: DateTime Axis Quickstart
recipes.description: Axis tick labels can be displayed using a time format.

recipes.name: DateTime Axis Values
recipes.description: DateTime axes are achieved using Microsoft's DateTime.ToOADate() and DateTime.FromOADate() methods to convert between dates and numeric values. Advanced users who wish to display data on DateTime axes may prefer to work with collections of doubles rather than collections of DateTimes.

recipes.name: Custom DateTime Label Format
recipes.description: Users can provide their own logic for customizing DateTime tick labels

recipes.name: DateTime Axis Fixed Interval Ticks
recipes.description: Make ticks render at fixed intervals. Optionally make the ticks render from a custom start date, rather than using the start date of the plot (e.g. to draw ticks on the hour every hour, or on the first of every month, etc).

recipes.name: Hide Grid
recipes.description: Grid lines can be hidden.

recipes.name: Grid Customization
recipes.description: Grid lines can be customized. Custom grid systems can be created to give developers full control of grid rendering, but the default grid can be interacted with to customize its appearance.

recipes.name: Axis Specific Grid Customization
recipes.description: Axis-specific styling properties are available for extensive axis-specific customization of grid line styling.

recipes.name: Grid Above Data
recipes.description: Grid lines are typically drawn beneath data, but grids can be configured to render on top of plottables too.

recipes.name: Grid with Top Axis
recipes.description: Grid lines use the bottom and left axes by default, but this behavior can be customized for plots which use other axes.

recipes.name: Grid Fill Colors
recipes.description: Regions between alternating pairs of major grid lines may be filled with a color specified by the user

recipes.name: Grid Fill Color in Dark Mode
recipes.description: Grid and plot styling can be customize to achieve a pleasing effect in dark mode

recipes.name: Frameless Plot
recipes.description: How to create a plot containing only the data area and no axes.

recipes.name: Fixed Padding
recipes.description: The plot can be arranged to achieve a fixed amount of padding on each side of the data area

recipes.name: Fixed Rectangle
recipes.description: The plot can be arranged so the data is drawn inside a fixed rectangle defined in pixel units

recipes.name: Legend Quickstart
recipes.description: Many plottables have a Label property that can be set so they appear in the legend.

recipes.name: Manual Legend Items
recipes.description: Legends may be constructed manually.

recipes.name: Legend Customization
recipes.description: Access the Legend object directly for advanced customization options.

recipes.name: Legend Orientation
recipes.description: Legend items may be arranged horizontally instead of vertically

recipes.name: Legend Wrapping
recipes.description: Legend items may wrap to improve display for a large number of items

recipes.name: Multiple Legends
recipes.description: Multiple legends may be added to a plot

recipes.name: Legend Outside the Plot
recipes.description: Use the ShowLegend() overload that accepts an Edge to display the legend outside the data area.

recipes.name: Automatic Legend Items Custom Font
recipes.description: Use custom fonts from TTF files in the legend.

recipes.name: Manual Legend Items Custom Font
recipes.description: Use custom fonts from TTF files in the legend (manual legend items).

recipes.name: Data Area Background Image
recipes.description: An image can be used for the background of the data area.

recipes.name: Figure Background Image
recipes.description: An image can be used for the background of a figure.

recipes.name: Color Interpolation
recipes.description: Colors can be mixed to createa range of colors. This strategy uses linear RGB interpolation.

recipes.name: Custom Font Files
recipes.description: Users can apply custom typefaces by loaded from font files.

recipes.name: Right Axis
recipes.description: New plots have one axis on every side. Axes on the right and top are invisible by default. To use the right axis, make it visible, then tell a plottable to use it.

recipes.name: Multi-Axis
recipes.description: Additional axes may be added to plots. Plottables are displayed using the coordinate system of the primary axes by default, but any plottable can be displayed using any X and Y axis.

recipes.name: Multiplot Quickstart
recipes.description: Use the Multiplot class to create figures with multiple subplots.

recipes.name: Multiplot Columns
recipes.description: The Multiplot's Layout property may be customized to achieve a column layout.

recipes.name: Multiplot Grid
recipes.description: The Multiplot's Layout property may be customized to achieve a grid layout.

recipes.name: Multiplot Custom Layout
recipes.description: The Multiplot's Layout property may be configured to achieve a fully custom layout.

recipes.name: Add Plottables Manually
recipes.description: Although the Plot.Add class has many helpful methods for creating plottable objects and adding them to the plot, users can instantiate plottable objects themselves and use Add.Plottable() to place it on the plot. This strategy allows users to create their own plottables (implementing IPlottable) with custom appearance or behavior.

recipes.name: Clearing Plots
recipes.description: Use Clear() to remove all plottables.

recipes.name: Removing a Plottable
recipes.description: Individual items may be removed from the plot.

recipes.name: Removing all Plottables of a Type
recipes.description: All plottables of a given type may be removed from a plot with a single command.

recipes.name: Moving plottables
recipes.description: The plottable list contains all plottables which will be rendered in order. Helper methods are available to move plottables to the front.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot
recipes.description: A scatter plot can be used to display X/Y data points.

recipes.name: Customizing Plottables
recipes.description: Most methods which add items to plots return the item the was added. Save the object that is returned and set its properties to customize it.

recipes.name: Signal Plot
recipes.description: Signal plots display Y values at evenly spaced X positions. Signal plots should be used instead of Scatter plots whenever possible.

recipes.name: Signal Plot Performance
recipes.description: Signal plots are so performant that they can interactively display millions of data points in real time.

recipes.name: Axis Labels
recipes.description: Plots have helper methods for quickly setting axis labels. Refer to other cookbook pages for additional axis customization options.

recipes.name: Style Helper Functions
recipes.description: Plots contain many objects which can be customized individually by assigning to their public properties, but helper methods exist in the Plot's Style object that make it easier to customize many items at once using a simpler API.

recipes.name: Axis Customization
recipes.description: Axis labels, tick marks, and frame can all be customized.

recipes.name: Palettes
recipes.description: A palette is a set of colors, and the Plot's palette defines the default colors to use when adding new plottables. ScottPlot comes with many standard palettes, but users may also create their own.

recipes.name: Arrow Shapes
recipes.description: Many standard arrow shapes are available

recipes.name: Line Styles
recipes.description: Many plot types have a LineStyle which can be customized.

recipes.name: Scale Factor
recipes.description: All components of an image can be scaled up or down in size by adjusting the ScaleFactor property. This is very useful for creating images that look nice on high DPI displays with display scaling enabled.

recipes.name: Hairline Mode
recipes.description: Hairline mode allows axis frames, tick marks, and grid lines to always be rendered a single pixel wide regardless of scale factor. Enable hairline mode to allow interactive plots to feel smoother when a large scale factor is in use.

recipes.name: Dark Mode
recipes.description: Plots can be created using dark mode by setting the colors of major plot components to ones consistent with a dark theme.

recipes.name: Colormap Steps
recipes.description: Colormaps can be used to generate a collection of discrete colors that can be applied to plottable objects.

recipes.name: Colormap Gradient from Colors
recipes.description: Colormaps can be created as a gradient between a collection of colors.

recipes.name: Custom Tick Formatters
recipes.description: Users can customize the logic used to create tick labels from tick positions. Old versions of ScottPlot achieved this using a ManualTickPositions method.

recipes.name: DateTimeAutomatic Tick Formatters
recipes.description: Users can customize the logic used to create datetime tick labels from tick positions.

recipes.name: Custom Tick Generators
recipes.description: Tick generators determine where ticks are to be placed and also contain logic for generating tick labels from tick positions. Alternative tick generators can be created and assigned to axes. Some common tick generators are provided with ScottPlot, and users also have the option create their own.

recipes.name: SetTicks Shortcut
recipes.description: The default axes have a SetTicks() helper method which replaces the default tick generator with a manual tick generator pre-loaded with the provided ticks.

recipes.name: Custom Tick Positions
recipes.description: Users desiring more control over major and minor tick positions and labels can instantiate a manual tick generator, set it up as desired, then assign it to the axis being customized

recipes.name: Rotated Tick Labels
recipes.description: Users can customize tick label rotation.

recipes.name: Rotated Tick with Long Labels
recipes.description: The axis size can be increased to accommodate rotated or long tick labels.

recipes.name: Disable Grid Lines
recipes.description: Users can disable grid lines for specific axes.

recipes.name: Minimum Tick Spacing
recipes.description: Space between ticks can be increased by setting a value to indicate the minimum distance between tick labels (in pixels).

recipes.name: Tick Density
recipes.description: Tick density can be adjusted as a fraction of the default value. Unlike MinimumTickSpacing, this strategy is aware of the size of tick labels and adjusts accordingly.

recipes.name: Tick Count
recipes.description: A target number of ticks can be provided and the automatic tick generator will attempt to place that number of ticks. This strategy allows tick density to decrease as the image size increases.

recipes.name: Minor Tick Density
recipes.description: Minor tick marks are automatically generated at intervals between major tick marks. By default they are evenly spaced, but their density may be customized.

recipes.name: Log Scale Tick Marks
recipes.description: The appearance of logarithmic scaling can be achieved by log-scaling the data to be displayed then customizing the minor ticks and grid.

recipes.name: Histogram Quickstart
recipes.description: A histogram can be created from a collection of values.

recipes.name: Histogram with Fixed Size Bins
recipes.description: A histogram can be created using manually defined bin sizes.

recipes.name: Filled Histogram
recipes.description: A filled histogram (one with no visible gaps between bars) can be achieved by setting the bar width to the bin size. However, anti-aliasing artifacts may cause white lines to appear between bars. Disable anti-aliasing for each bar to improve appearance of such plots.

recipes.name: Histogram of Probabilities
recipes.description: Histograms may be displayed as the probability for each value falling inside a bin

recipes.name: Histogram with Probability Curve
recipes.description: A probability curve may be generated for a Gaussian distributed sample.

recipes.name: Histogram with Second Axis Probability
recipes.description: A probability curve may be placed on a secondary axis to allow counts to be displayed alongside probabilities with percent units

recipes.name: Multiple Histograms
recipes.description: Demonstrates how to use semitransparent bars to display histograms from overlapping datasets

recipes.name: Cumulative Probability Histogram
recipes.description: A cumulative probability histogram represents the cumulative sum of probabilities or relative frequencies up to each bin, providing a running total of the probability distribution. It is especially useful for evaluating and comparing the distribution of multiple populations.

recipes.name: Supported Font Detection
recipes.description: ScottPlot comes with font detection methods which help identify the best installed font for displaying text which may contain international characters.

recipes.name: Automatic Font Detection
recipes.description: The Plot's Style class contains a method which automatically sets the fonts of common plot objects to the font most likely able to display the characters they contain.

recipes.name: Linear Regression
recipes.description: Fit a line to a collection of X/Y data points.

recipes.name: Annotation Quickstart
recipes.description: Annotations are labels you can place on the data area of a plot. Unlike Text added to the plot (which is placed in coordinate units on the axes), Annotations are positioned relative to the data area (in pixel units) and do not move as the plot is panned and zoomed.

recipes.name: Annotation Customization
recipes.description: Annotations can be extensively customized.

recipes.name: Annotation Positions
recipes.description: Annotations are aligned with the data area.

recipes.name: Arrow Quickstart
recipes.description: Arrows can be placed on plots to point to a location in coordinate space and extensively customized.

recipes.name: Axis Lines
recipes.description: Axis lines are vertical or horizontal lines that span an entire axis.

recipes.name: Axis Line Label
recipes.description: Axis lines have labels that can be used to display arbitrary text on the axes they are attached to.

recipes.name: Axis Line Label Positioning
recipes.description: Axis line labels can have custom positioning, including rotation and alignment.

recipes.name: Axis Line Style
recipes.description: Axis lines have extensive customization options.

recipes.name: Axis Line In Legend
recipes.description: Axis lines will be added to the legend if their Text property is set unless their ExcludeFromLegend property is true.

recipes.name: Ignore When Autoscaling
recipes.description: Calling Plot.Axes.AutoScale() or middle-clicking the plot will set the axis limits to fit the data. By default the position of axis lines and spans are included in automatic axis limit calculations, but a flag can be set to ignore certain plottables when automatically scaling the plot.

recipes.name: Axis Span Quickstart
recipes.description: Axis spans label a range of an axis. Vertical spans shade the full width of a vertical range, and horizontal spans shade the full height of a horizontal range.

recipes.name: Axis Span Styling
recipes.description: Axis spans can be extensively customized.

recipes.name: Bar Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: Bar plots can be added from a series of values.

recipes.name: Bar Plot Legend
recipes.description: A collection of bars can appear in the legend as a single item.

recipes.name: Bar with Value Labels
recipes.description: Set the `Label` property of bars to have text displayed above each bar.

recipes.name: Bar with Value Labels (horizontal)
recipes.description: Set the `Label` property of bars to have text displayed beside (left or right) of each bar.

recipes.name: Bar Positioning
recipes.description: The exact position and size of each bar may be customized.

recipes.name: Bars with Error
recipes.description: Bars can have errorbars.

recipes.name: Bars with Labeled Ticks
recipes.description: Bars can be labeled by manually specifying axis tick mark positions and labels.

recipes.name: Stacked Bar Plot
recipes.description: Bars can be positioned on top of each other.

recipes.name: Grouped Bar Plot
recipes.description: Bars can be grouped by position and color.

recipes.name: Horizontal Bar Plot
recipes.description: Bar plots can be displayed horizontally.

recipes.name: Stacked Bar Chart
recipes.description: Bars can be stacked to present data in groups.

recipes.name: Box Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: Box plots can be created individually and added to the plot.

recipes.name: Box Plot Groups
recipes.description: Each collection of boxes added to the plot gets styled the same and appears as a single item in the legend. Add multiple bar series plots with defined X positions to give the appearance of grouped data.

recipes.name: Callout Quickstart
recipes.description: Callouts display a label and are connected with an arrow that marks a point on the plot.

recipes.name: Rectangular Contour Plot
recipes.description: A rectangular contour plot with evenly spaced points can be created from a 2D array of 3D points.

recipes.name: Irregular Contour Plot
recipes.description: A contour plot can be created from a collection of 3D data points placed arbitrarily in X/Y plane.

recipes.name: Contour Lines with Heatmap
recipes.description: Contour lines may be placed on top of heatmaps.

recipes.name: Contour Lines with Colormap
recipes.description: If a colormap is provided it will be used to color each line in the colormap according to its value.

recipes.name: Coxcomb Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: A Coxcomb chart is a pie graph where the angle of slices is constant but the radii are not.

recipes.name: Crosshair Quickstart
recipes.description: A Crosshair combines a horizontal axis line and vertical axis line to mark a location in coordinate space.

recipes.name: Crosshair Customization
recipes.description: Crosshairs can be extensively customized.

recipes.name: Ellipse Quickstart
recipes.description: Ellipses can be added to plots

recipes.name: Circle Quickstart
recipes.description: Circles can be added to plots. Circles are really Ellipses with the same X and Y radius. Note that circles appear as ellipses unless the plot has a square coordinate system.

recipes.name: Circle with Locked Scale
recipes.description: For circles to always appear circular, the coordinate system must be forced to always display square-shaped pixels. This can be achieved by enabling the axis scale lock.

recipes.name: Ellipse Styling
recipes.description: Ellipses styles can be extensively customized

recipes.name: Ellipse Rotation
recipes.description: Ellipses can also be rotated

recipes.name: Error Bar Quickstart
recipes.description: Error Bars go well with scatter plots.

recipes.name: ErrorBar Values
recipes.description: Error size can be set for all dimensions.

recipes.name: FillY From Array Data
recipes.description: FillY plots can be created from X, Y1, and Y2 arrays.

recipes.name: FillY From Scatter Plots
recipes.description: FillY plots can be created from two scatter plots that share the same X values.

recipes.name: FillY with Custom Type
recipes.description: FillY plots can be created from data of any type if a conversion function is supplied.

recipes.name: FillY Plot Styling
recipes.description: FillY plots can be customized using public properties.

recipes.name: Candlestick Chart
recipes.description: Candlestick charts use symbols to display price data. The rectangle indicates open and close prices, and the center line indicates minimum and maximum price for the given time period. Color indicates whether the price increased or decreased between open and close.

recipes.name: OHLC Chart
recipes.description: OHLC charts use symbols to display price data (open, high, low, and close) for specific time ranges.

recipes.name: Finance Chart with Custom Time Bins
recipes.description: Finance charts can display price range information over arbitrary time scales.

recipes.name: Price on Right
recipes.description: Finance charts can be created which display price information on the right axis.

recipes.name: Simple Moving Average
recipes.description: Tools exist for creating simple moving average (SMA) curves and displaying them next to finanial data.

recipes.name: Bollinger Bands
recipes.description: Tools exist for creating Bollinger Bands which display weighted moving mean and variance for time series financial data.

recipes.name: Candlestick Chart Without Gaps
recipes.description: When the DateTimes stored in OHLC objects are used to determine the horizontal position of candlesticks, periods without data like weekends and holidays appear as gaps in the plot. Enabling sequential mode causes the plot to ignore the OHLC DateTimes and display candles at integer positions starting from zero. Users can customize the tick generator to display dates instead of numbers on the horizontal axis if desired.

recipes.name: OHLC Chart Without Gaps
recipes.description: When the DateTimes stored in OHLC objects are used to determine the horizontal position, periods without data like weekends and holidays appear as gaps in the plot. Enabling sequential mode causes the plot to ignore the OHLC DateTimes and place OHLCs at integer positions starting from zero. Users can customize the tick generator to display dates instead of numbers on the horizontal axis if desired.

recipes.name: Stock Symbol Background
recipes.description: Stock symbol information can be displayed beneath the plot using the background text feature.

recipes.name: Stock Symbol Multiline
recipes.description: Stock symbol information can be displayed beneath the plot using the multiline background text feature.

recipes.name: Finance Chart Dark Mode
recipes.description: A dark mode finance plot can be achieved by customizing color options of the candles and figure.

recipes.name: Function Quickstart
recipes.description: Create a function plot from a formula.

recipes.name: Function Limit X
recipes.description: A function can be limited to a range of X values.

recipes.name: Heatmap Quickstart
recipes.description: Heatmaps can be created from 2D arrays

recipes.name: Inverted Heatmap
recipes.description: Heatmaps can be inverted by reversing the order of colors in the colormap

recipes.name: Heatmap with custom Colormap
recipes.description: A heatmap's Colormap is the logic used to convert from cell value to cell color and they can set by the user. ScottPlot comes with many common colormaps, but users may implement IColormap and apply their own. A colorbar can be added to indicate which colors map to which values.

recipes.name: Multiple Colorbars
recipes.description: Multiple colorbars may be added to plots.

recipes.name: Colorbar Title
recipes.description: A colorbar displays a colormap on an edge of the plot, and it has an optional label which can be customized to display a title.

recipes.name: Colorbar Tick Formatter
recipes.description: Colorbars have an optional custom tick formatter that allows users to control the string format of tick labels.

recipes.name: Flipped Heatmap
recipes.description: Heatmaps can be flipped horizontally and/or vertically

recipes.name: Smooth Heatmap
recipes.description: Enable the `Smooth` property for anti-aliased rendering

recipes.name: Transparent Cells
recipes.description: Assign double.NaN to a heatmap cell to make it transparent.

recipes.name: Global Transparency
recipes.description: The transparency of the entire heatmap can be adjusted.

recipes.name: Alpha Map
recipes.description: An alpha map (a 2d array of byte values) can be used to apply custom transparency to each cell of a heatmap.

recipes.name: Frameless Heatmap
recipes.description: A frameless heatmap can be achieved by disabling axis labels and ticks, then setting the margins to 0 so the data area tightly fits the data.

recipes.name: HeatmapCellAlignment
recipes.description: Heatmap cells are aligned in their centers by default. This means that the bottom left cell will be centered at (0, 0), and its lower left corner will be to the lower left of the origin. Setting sell alignment to lower left causes the lower left of the heatmap to be exactly at (0, 0).

recipes.name: Heatmap Cell Size
recipes.description: Dimensions of a heatmap may be set by specifying how large a cell should be in pixel units.

recipes.name: Heatmap with Manual Color Range
recipes.description: The user can define the range of values to represent with colors in the colormap. Values outside that range will be clipped to the nearest color in the colormap.

recipes.name: Image Rectangle
recipes.description: An image can be drawn inside a rectangle defined in coordinate units.

recipes.name: Line Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: Line plots are placed with a start and end location in coordinate space. Their styles can be customized.

recipes.name: Line Plot Shapes
recipes.description: Line plots can be styled using a LineStyle.

recipes.name: Line Plot Legend
recipes.description: Line plots with labels appear in the legend.

recipes.name: Lollipop Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: Lollipop plots can be created from a sequence of values

recipes.name: Lollipop Positions
recipes.description: The position of each lollipop may be defined.

recipes.name: Lollipop Plot Customizations
recipes.description: The stem line and head marker can be extensively customized.

recipes.name: Horizontal Lollipop Plot
recipes.description: Change the lollipop plot's Orientation to Horizontal to cause stems to be drawn horizontally instead of vertically.

recipes.name: Marker Quickstart
recipes.description: Markers are symbols placed at a location in coordinate space. Their shape, size, and color can be customized.

recipes.name: Marker Shapes
recipes.description: Standard marker shapes are provided, but advanced users are able to create their own as well.

recipes.name: Marker Legend
recipes.description: Markers with labels appear in the legend.

recipes.name: Many Markers
recipes.description: Collections of markers that are all styled the same may be added to the plot

recipes.name: Marker with Colormap
recipes.description: A colormap may be used to style a collection of markers

recipes.name: Image Marker
recipes.description: An ImageMarker can be placed on the plot to display an image centered at a location in coordinate space.

recipes.name: Phasor Line Plot
recipes.description: A phasor line plot contains a collection of polar coordinates which are rendered as arrows.

recipes.name: Phasor Plot with Labels
recipes.description: Text labels may be applied to individual arrows of a phasor plot.

recipes.name: Pie Chart from Values
recipes.description: A pie chart can be created from a few values.

recipes.name: Pie Chart from Slices
recipes.description: A pie chart can be created from a collection of slices.

recipes.name: Donut from Slices
recipes.description: A donut chart is a pie chart with an open center. Donut charts can be created from a collection of slices.

recipes.name: Pie Chart Rotation
recipes.description: Pie charts may be rotated to control where the first slice begins.

recipes.name: Pie Slice Labels
recipes.description: Slice labels can be displayed centered with the slice at a customizable distance from the center of the pie.

recipes.name: Pie with Percent Labels
recipes.description: Slice labels may be adapted to display any text (including numerical values) centered over each slice.

recipes.name: Pie with Different Labels
recipes.description: Pie slices may have labels independent from those displayed in the legend.

recipes.name: Polar Axis
recipes.description: A polar axis can be added to the plot, then other plot types (marker, line, scatter, etc.) can be placed on top of it using ints helper methods to translate polar coordinates to Cartesian units.

recipes.name: Polar Axis Rotation
recipes.description: A polar axis may be rotated to define the angle of the 0 degree spoke.

recipes.name: Polar Axis with Arrows
recipes.description: Arrows can be placed on a polar coordinate system with their base at the center and their tips used to indicate points in polar space. The Phaser plot type uses this strategy to display collections of similarly styled arrows.

recipes.name: Polar Axis Styling
recipes.description: The lines of polar axes may be extensively styled. Polar axes have radial spokes (straight lines that extend from the origin to the maximum radius) and circular axis lines (concentric circles centered at the origin).

recipes.name: Polar Axis Spoke Labels
recipes.description: Polar axis spokes may be individually labeled.

recipes.name: Polar Axis Tick Labels
recipes.description: Polar axis ticks are marked by circles which may be individually labeled.

recipes.name: Polar Axis Line Customization
recipes.description: The angle and length of spokes and position of circles can be manually defined. Each spoke and circle may also be individually styled.

recipes.name: Polar Radar Plot
recipes.description: Combining a polar axis with polygons is an alternative strategy for building radar plots.

recipes.name: Population Quickstart
recipes.description: A Population can be created from a collection of values, styled as desired, and placed anywhere on the plot.

recipes.name: Population Box Plot
recipes.description: Population statistics can be displayed using box plots.

recipes.name: Population Box Values
recipes.description: The values displayed by the box midline, body, and whisker can be configured by assigning a static function to the box value configuration property.

recipes.name: Population Bar Styling
recipes.description: The bar symbol in population plots can be extensively styled.

recipes.name: Population Box Styling
recipes.description: The box symbol in population plots can be extensively styled.

recipes.name: Population Marker Styling
recipes.description: The data markers in population plots can be extensively styled.

recipes.name: Population Arrangement
recipes.description: The user may customize where data is drawn relative to the bar or box. Centering everything can be used to achieve an effect where data points are drawn over the bar or box.

recipes.name: Population Groups
recipes.description: Groups of populations can be achieved by customizing position, color, axis labels, and legend items.

recipes.name: Radar Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: A radar chart can be created from a single array of values.

recipes.name: Radar Plot with Multiple Series
recipes.description: A single radar chart can be used to display values from multiple series using a 2D array

recipes.name: Radar Legend
recipes.description: Collections of radar values (radar series) can be labeled so they appear in the legend

recipes.name: Radar Series Customization
recipes.description: Radar plots have a collection of RadarSeries objects which each describe a set of values and the styling information used to display it as a shape on the radar plot. Users may change properties of radar series objects to achieve a high level of customization over each shape.

recipes.name: Radar Spoke Labels
recipes.description: Labels can be assigned to spokes to label values around the circumference of the radar plot

recipes.name: Radar Radial Tick Labels
recipes.description: Radar radial tick positions and labels may be defined by the user

recipes.name: Radar with Straight Lines
recipes.description: Radial ticks may be rendered using straight lines instead of circles

recipes.name: Radial gauge from values
recipes.description: A radial gauge chart can be created from a few values.

recipes.name: Gauge Colors
recipes.description: Gauge colors can be customized by changing the default palette.

recipes.name: Negative Values
recipes.description: Radial gauge plots support positive and negative values.

recipes.name: Sequential Gauge Mode
recipes.description: Sequential gauge mode indicates that the base of each gauge starts at the tip of the previous gauge.

recipes.name: Reverse Order
recipes.description: Gauges are displayed from the center outward by default but the order can be customized.

recipes.name: Single Gauge Mode
recipes.description: The SingleGauge mode draws all gauges stacked together as a single gauge. This is useful for showing a progress gauges composed of many individual smaller gauges.

recipes.name: Gauge Direction
recipes.description: The direction of gauges can be customized. Clockwise is used by default.

recipes.name: Gauge Size
recipes.description: The empty space between gauges can be adjusted as a fraction of their width.

recipes.name: Gauge Starting Angle
recipes.description: The starting angle for gauges can be customized. 270 for North (default value), 0 for East, 90 for South, 180 for West, etc.

recipes.name: Gauge Angular Range
recipes.description: By default gauges are full circles (360 degrees) but smaller gauges can be created by customizing the gauge size.

recipes.name: Show Levels
recipes.description: The value of each gauge is displayed as text by default but this behavior can be overridden. Note that this is different than the labels fiels which is what appears in the legened.

recipes.name: Gauge Label Position
recipes.description: Gauge level text is positioned at the tip of each gauge by default, but this position can be adjusted by the user.

recipes.name: Gauge Label Font Percentage
recipes.description: Size of the gauge level text as a fraction of the gauge width.

recipes.name: Gauge Label Color
recipes.description: Level text fonts may be customized.

recipes.name: Gauge Labels in Legend
recipes.description: Radial gauge labels will appear in the legend if they are assigned.

recipes.name: Background Gauges Dim
recipes.description: By default the full range of each gauge is drawn as a semitransparent ring. The amount of transparency can be adjusted as desired.

recipes.name: Background Gauges Normalization
recipes.description: Gauge backgrounds are drawn as full circles by default. This behavior can be disabled to draw partial backgrounds for non-circular gauges.

recipes.name: ScaleBar Quickstart
recipes.description: A ScaleBar can be added to a plot to convey scale information allowing axis frames, ticks, and labels to be hidden.

recipes.name: ScaleBar Labels
recipes.description: Text may be added to each dimension of an L shaped scalebar

recipes.name: ScaleBar Styling
recipes.description: The ScaleBar has many properties which may be customized

recipes.name: ScaleBar Single Dimension
recipes.description: Set Width or Height to 0 to cause the ScaleBar to use a single axis only

recipes.name: Scatter Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: Scatter plots can be created from two arrays containing X and Y values.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot Coordinates
recipes.description: Scatter plots can be created from a collection of Coordinates.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot Data Type
recipes.description: Scatter plots can be created from any numeric data type, not just double.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot of List Data
recipes.description: Scatter plots can be created from Lists, but be very cafeful not to add or remove items while a render is occurring or you may throw an index exception. See documentation about the Render Lock system for details.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot with Lines Only
recipes.description: The `ScatterLine()` method can be used to create a scatter plot with a line only (marker size is set to 0).

recipes.name: Scatter Plot with Points Only
recipes.description: The `ScatterPoints()` method can be used to create a scatter plot with markers only (line width is set to 0).

recipes.name: Scatter Plot Styling
recipes.description: Scatter plots can be extensively styled by interacting with the object that is returned after a scatter plot is added. Assign text to a scatter plot's Label property to allow it to appear in the legend.

recipes.name: Scatter Line Patterns
recipes.description: Several line patterns are available

recipes.name: Scatter Generic
recipes.description: Scatter plots support generic data types, although double is typically the most performant.

recipes.name: Scatter DateTime
recipes.description: A scatter plot may use DateTime units but be sure to setup the respective axis to display using DateTime format.

recipes.name: Step Plot
recipes.description: Scatter plots can be created using a step plot display where points are connected with right angles instead of diagnal lines. The direction of the steps can be customized.

recipes.name: Scatter with Gaps
recipes.description: NaN values in a scatter plot's data will appear as gaps in the line.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot with Smooth Lines
recipes.description: Scatter plots draw straight lines between points by default, but setting the Smooth property allows the scatter plot to connect points with smooth lines. Lines are smoothed using cubic spline interpolation.

recipes.name: Smooth Line Tension
recipes.description: Tension of smooth lines can be adjusted for some smoothing strategies. Low tensions lead to 'overshoot' and high tensions produce curveswhich appear more like straight lines.

recipes.name: Smooth Scatter without Overshoot
recipes.description: The quadratic half point path strategy allows scatter plots to be displayed with smooth lines connecting points, but lines are eased in and out of points so they never 'overshoot' the values vertically.

recipes.name: Limiting Display with Render Indexes
recipes.description: Although a scatter plot may contain a very large amount of data, much of it may be unpopulated. The user can define min and max render indexes, and only values within that range will be displayed when the scatter plot is rendered.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot with Fill
recipes.description: The area beneath a scatter plot can be filled.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot Filled to a Value
recipes.description: The base of the fill can be defined.

recipes.name: Scatter Plot Filled Above and Below
recipes.description: Filled areas above and below the FillY value can be individually customized

recipes.name: Scatter Plot with Gradient Fill
recipes.description: The area beneath a scatter plot can be filled with a custom gradient of colors.

recipes.name: Scatter Scale and Offset
recipes.description: Scatter plot points can be multiplied by custom X and Y scale factors, or shifted horizontally or vertically using X and Y offset values.

recipes.name: Stacked Filled Line Plot
recipes.description: A stacked filled line plot effect can be achieved by overlapping ScatterLines that fill area.

recipes.name: Rectangle
recipes.description: A rectangle can be added to the plot and styled as desired.

recipes.name: Circle
recipes.description: A circle can be placed on the plot and styled as desired.

recipes.name: Ellipse
recipes.description: An ellipse can be placed on the plot and styled as desired.

recipes.name: Polygon Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: Polygon plots can be added from a series of vertices, and must be in clockwise order.

recipes.name: Polygon Plot Styling
recipes.description: Polygon plots can be fully customized.

recipes.name: Signal Plot Quickstart
recipes.description: Signal plots are best for extremely large datasets. They use render using special optimizations that allow highspeed interactivity with plots containing millions of data points.

recipes.name: Signal Plot Styling
recipes.description: Signal plots can be styled in a variety of ways.

recipes.name: Signal Offset
recipes.description: Signal plots can be offset by a given X and Y value.

recipes.name: Signal Scaling
recipes.description: Signal plots can be scaled vertically according to a user-defined amount.

recipes.name: Signal Marker Size
recipes.description: Signal plots can have markers displayed at each point which are only visible when the plot is zoomed in.

recipes.name: Partial Signal Rendering
recipes.description: Even if a signal plot references a large array of data, rendering can be limited to a range of values. If set,only the range of data between the minimum and maximum render indexes will be displayed.

recipes.name: Signal Generic
recipes.description: Signal plots support generic data types, although double is typically the most performant.

recipes.name: Signal DateTime
recipes.description: A signal plot may use DateTime units but be sure to setup the respective axis to display using DateTime format.

recipes.name: SignalConst Quickstart
recipes.description: SignalConst can display data with millions of points at high framerates, ideal for interactive manipulation of large datasets.

recipes.name: SignalXY Quickstart
recipes.description: SignalXY plots are a high performance plot type for X/Y data where the X values are always ascending.

recipes.name: SignalXY Generic
recipes.description: SignalXY plots support generic data types, although double is typically the most performant.

recipes.name: SignalXY DateTime Axis
recipes.description: SignalXY plots can display unevenly spaced time series data using a DateTime horizontal axis.

recipes.name: Partial SignalXY Rendering
recipes.description: Even if a SignalXY plot references a large array of data, rendering can be limited to a range of values. If set,only the range of data between the minimum and maximum render indexes will be displayed.

recipes.name: SignalXY Offset
recipes.description: A fixed offset can be applied to SignalXY plots.

recipes.name: SignalXY Scaling
recipes.description: SignalXY plots can be scaled vertically according to a user-defined amount.

recipes.name: Vertical SignalXY
recipes.description: Although SignalXY plots typically display data left-to-right, it is possible to use this plot type to display data bottom-to-top.

recipes.name: Vertical SignalXY with Inverted X Axis
recipes.description: Demonstrates how to display a rotated SignalXY plot (so it goes from bottom to top) which is also displayed on an inverted horizontal axis (where positive values are on the left).

recipes.name: Vertical SignalXY with Inverted Y Axis
recipes.description: Demonstrates how to display a rotated SignalXY plot on an inverted vertical axis so data goes from top to bottom.

recipes.name: SignalXY with Markers
recipes.description: Users can enable a marker to be displayedat each data point. However, this can reduce performance for extremely large datasets.

recipes.name: Text Quickstart
recipes.description: Text can be placed anywhere in coordinate space.

recipes.name: Text Formatting
recipes.description: Text formatting can be extensively customized.

recipes.name: Line Height
recipes.description: Multiline labels have a default line height estimated from the typeface and font size, however line height may be manually defined by the user.

recipes.name: Text Offset
recipes.description: The offset properties can be used to fine-tune text position in pixel units

recipes.name: Vector Field Quickstart
recipes.description: Vectors (representing a magnitude and direction) can be placed at specific points in coordinate space to display as a vector field.

recipes.name: Vector Field Colormap
recipes.description: Vector field arrows can be colored according to their magnitude.
